metadata.title: Enantioselective carbon dioxide extrusion from allyl phenyl carbonates by nickel, palladium and rhodium catalysts

L15 Lll Enantioselective Carbon Dioxide Extrusion from AUyl Phenyl Carbonates by Nickel, Palladium and Rhodium Catalysts JOURNAL OF MOLECULAR CATALYSIS GIAMBATTISTA CONSIGLIO, MICHELANGELO SCALONE* and FRANCO RAMA** Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Department of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, ETH-Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich (Switzerland) (Received October 6,1988; accepted December 8, 1988) Enantioselective syntheses by homogeneous transition metal complexes in which asymmetric carbon atoms arise from the formation of new carbon- heteroatom bonds have attracted recent interest [1]. In particular, new carbon-oxygen bonds are formed in enantioselective epoxidation [2], in the allylic oxidation of olefinic hydrocarbons [3] and in the cyclization of 2-allylphenols to dihydrobenzofuran [4]; this last reaction represents mecha- nistically a Wacker-type oxidation [5]. We report here our preliminary results concerning an enantioselective synthesis of allyl phenyl ethers (Scheme 1). Although apparently related to the above cyclization [4], it nevertheless takes place through the formation of allylic intermediates. This synthesis takes advantage of the facile decarboxylation of allyl phenyl carbonates brought about by palladium complexes [6] or by compounds of other transition metals [7], and of the much higher reactivity of allyl phenyl carbonates as compared to allyl phenyl ethers towards allylic activation by transition metal complexes [8, 9]. A higher reactivity of the reaction prod- uct with respect to the starting material would, in fact, eventually lead to racemic products. Some results involving isomeric butenyl phenyl carbonates Cat' -CO-, Cat" Scheme 1. *Pregent address: F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Co., Zentrale Forschungseinheiten, CH-4002 Basle, Switzerland. **Present address: Istituto G. Donegani S.p.A, Via G. Fauser, 4, 1-28100 Novara, Italy. 0304-6102/89/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands L12 and different metal compound/chiral ligand combinations are reported in Table 1. The decarboxylation reactions were carried out in tetrahydrofuran solution at room temperature for the palladium and nickel catalysts and at reflux for the rhodium systems. Reaction times ranged from several minutes to several hours using a 3 mmol concentration of the catalyst and a catalyst: substrate ratio of about 1:1000. The ratio metal atom:chiral ligand was 1:1. Completion of the reaction was monitored by gas chromatography, which also gave the isomeric composition of the reaction products. The reaction mixture was separated from the catalyst through bulb-to-bulb distillation under high vacuum (0.01 mmHg) and then washed with aqueous NaOH. The product was isolated by distillation after drying on NazSC^ (b.p. 84 C/ 12 mmHg) for the determination of the optical rotatory power. Yields were 60 - 90% for the nickel and palladium catalysts, and 50 - 80% for the rhodium system. In all the catalytic systems used in the decarboxylation reaction, both the linear and the chiral ethers (Scheme 1) are present. The diastereomeric composition of the linear product (Z or E) was not determined. The regio- selectivity is quite high for the rhodium-catalyzed reaction. For the pal- ladium-based catalytic systems, the regioselectivity depends on which diphosphine ligand is used; for the bco-dpp ligand, it depends on the geom- etry of the substrate. Enantioselectivity for the rhodium/chiraphos and nickel/chiraphos catalytic systems depends on the geometry of the substrate. The best optical yield (23.4%) was obtained with the rhodium system starting with (E)-2- butenyl phenyl carbonate as the substrate. It should be noted that the two metal systems with the same chiral ligand ((iS,iS)-chiraphos) cause preferential formation of the opposite enantiomeric phenyl ether. Due to their heterochirality, (.R,.R)-cypenphos and (S,S)-chiraphos cause preferential formation of the opposite enantiomer in the decarboxyla- tion reaction catalyzed by palladium. In the case of chiraphos, the enantio- selectivity is not influenced by the geometry of the substrate, whereas it is for the cypenphos ligand. This effect is more dramatic using the (S,S)- bco-dpp ligand, which cause preferential formation of the opposite ether enantiomer starting with either (E)- or (Z)-2-butenyl phenyl carbonate. The palladium/(S,S)-chiraphos catalytic system also causes an enantioselective isomerization of ( )-4-phenoxy-2-butene to ( )(JF2)-3-phenoxy-l-butene (20% isomerization after 95 h reaction, 3.8% optical purity). In the en- antiomer-selective isomerization ofracemic 3-phenoxy-l-butene, the ( )(R)- enantiomer is also preferentially isomerized; at 22% conversion after 25 h a product enriched in the (+)(<S)-enantiomer (1.9% optical purity) was recovered. In Scheme 2 the relationship is presented in terms of geometries of starting materials and products by assuming Tr-allylic intermediates. These would arise by inversion of configuration from the allylic carbonate [14] and would be attacked by the phenoxide nucleophile distal to the palladium <u 4J SSE J3 4J A c^yo? [15], to cause a net retention of configuration of the whole reaction. Dif- ferences in enantiomeric and isomeric compositions of the reaction products imply that under our reaction conditions interconversion among the four possible [16] diastereomeric allyl intermediates is somewhat slower as compared to the nucleophilic attack by the phenolate ion. We cannot rationalize the difference in behaviour by the metal systems used in combi- nation with the chiraphos ligand. For the palladium catalyst, it would appear that an increase in the strength of chelation by the diphosphine ligand [17] causes an acceleration of the interconversion of the allylic intermediate compared with the rate of subsequent attack. The results of the enantio- selective isomerization of (Z)-4-phenoxy-2-butene and of the enantiomer- selective isomerization of 3-phenoxy-l-butene support the conclusion that these reactions proceed through a common intermediate. Preliminary investigation of the enantioselective synthesis of alkyi allyl ethers using the palladium catalysts of Table 1 gave very low chemical yields. L15 References 1 (a) M. Emziane, K. I.
